text: This review was undertaken by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data in The Hague. The study was written by Seth Caldwell with internal and external
label: BODY

text: review by Håvard Hegre, Kim Kristensen, Erin Lentz, Leonardo Milano, Ben Parker, Josée Poirier, Manu Singh,
label: BODY

text: Sarah Telford, and Marie Wagner. Graphic design is by Lena Kim. The Centre for Humanitarian Data can be
label: BODY

text: contacted at centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
label: HH1

text: Anticipatory action enables humanitarian organizations to get ahead of a predictable shock in order to
label: BODY

text: reduce its impact on vulnerable people. Since 2020, the Centre for Humanitarian Data has been supporting
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s anticipatory action frameworks in over a dozen countries. Our work is focused on developing
label: BODY

text: the trigger mechanisms, which provide a threshold for when to release funds and take action ahead of a
label: BODY

text: projected shock.
label: BODY

text: While the current anticipatory action pilots have shown that we can use data and models to predict a coming
label: BODY

text: crisis, they have been limited to climate events and disease outbreaks. OCHA leadership and stakeholders
label: BODY

text: have asked if it is feasible to use similar techniques to predict and act ahead of a conflict.
label: BODY

text: Predicting war, coups and riots has been a goal for a generation of social studies researchers. We reviewed a
label: BODY

text: wide array of literature from several ongoing research projects across academia, the security sector and the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector. Advances in machine learning and newly available historical datasets and predictors
label: BODY

text: have given momentum to the field. Nevertheless, the problem of conflict prediction remains complex and
label: BODY

text: hard to solve.
label: BODY

text: In our research, we evaluated three types of conflict prediction models – classification, risk prediction,
label: BODY

text: and continuous prediction. We found insufficient justification for exclusively relying on conflict prediction
label: BODY

text: models to drive anticipatory action due to several factors:
label: BODY

text: •	 Poor performance in predicting the onset of new conflicts.
label: BODY

text: •	 The lack of clear connection between predicted conflict and resulting humanitarian impact.
label: BODY

text: •	 The dominance of ongoing conflict as a predictor of future conflict.
label: BODY

text: To make use of conflict prediction for anticipatory action in the humanitarian sector, we recommend that
label: BODY

text: future work:
label: BODY

text: •	 Utilize flexible models that do not pre-suppose a theoretical framework of conflict causality.
label: BODY

text: •	 Focus models on predicting shifts in conflicts, such as an increase in intensity or onset.
label: BODY

text: •	 Explore the use of human inputs through superforecasters or prediction markets and use local data to
label: BODY

text: improve model performance in specific contexts.
label: BODY

text: •	 Improve predictions on the humanitarian impact of conflict as opposed to conflict itself.
label: BODY

text: •	 Ensure that model development and evaluation is done in a reproducible and transparent way that
label: BODY

text: highlights the model performance in all relevant metrics.
label: BODY

text: •	 Learn from the state-of-the-art research underway in the academic field and ensure that applied
label: BODY

text: research is relevant for humanitarian decision making.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 1. INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: Anticipatory action enables humanitarian organizations to get ahead of a predictable shock in order to
label: BODY

text: reduce its impact on vulnerable people. Since 2020, the Centre for Humanitarian Data has been supporting
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s anticipatory action frameworks in over a dozen countries. Our work is focused on developing
label: BODY

text: the trigger mechanisms, which provide a threshold for when to release funds and take action ahead of a
label: BODY

text: projected shock.
label: BODY

text: While the current anticipatory action pilots have shown that we can use data and models to predict a
label: BODY

text: coming crisis, they have been limited to climate events and disease outbreaks. Yet, conflict is a key driver of
label: BODY

text: food insecurity globally, with nearly 100 million people experiencing food insecurity in 23 conflict affected
label: BODY

text: countries in 2020.1 With 36 armed conflicts reported in 2021, conflict will continue to drive and exacerbate
label: BODY

text: not just food insecurity but a myriad of other humanitarian needs.2 Given this negative impact, OCHA
label: BODY

text: leadership and stakeholders have asked if it is feasible to use similar techniques to predict and act ahead of
label: BODY

text: a conflict.
label: BODY

text: 1.1 MOTIVATION
label: HH1

text: The Centre’s research focused on answering two questions3 on the feasibility of forecasting conflict for
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action:
label: BODY

text: 1.2 APPROACH
label: HH1

text: 1     UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 2022. Global Humanitarian Overview 2022.
label: BODY

text: 2    Escola de Cultura de Pau, 2022. Alert 2022!
label: BODY

text: 3    Marie Wagner and Catalina Jaime, 2020. An Agenda for Expanding Forecast-Based Action to Situations of Conflict, Global Public Policy Institute
label: BODY

text: working paper.
label: BODY

text: Conflict does not appear out of nowhere. Politics, the environment or competition for resources may all
label: BODY

text: contribute to a flare-up of violence. Conflict prediction generally relies on an analysis of historical conflict
label: BODY

text: and contributing factors to build a model of where and when it may break out in the future.
label: BODY

text: However, the range of factors and differences across contexts can make it challenging for any data-driven
label: BODY

text: model to accurately predict conflict. We reviewed existing literature and models to see how well they
label: BODY

text: performed in predicting conflict and the feasibility of applying these models to anticipatory action. In this
label: BODY

text: paper, we define and evaluate three types of conflict prediction models – classification, risk prediction, and
label: BODY

text: continuous prediction – and conclude with a set of recommendations and next steps for the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector.
label: BODY

text: How accurate are conflict forecasts?
label: BODY

text: How well can various sources predict different types of conflict in specific situations?
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 2. TYPES OF PREDICTION
label: HH1

text: The literature is dominated by models that fall under three types of conflict prediction: classification, risk
label: BODY

text: prediction, and continuous prediction. The three types of models produce different types of information.
label: BODY

text: •	 Classification models categorically predict whether or not a conflict will occur in a particular area and
label: BODY

text: time, through either binary (e.g., yes/no) or multiclass classification (e.g., major, minor or no conflict,
label: BODY

text: or a 1-5 scale).
label: BODY

text: •	 Risk prediction is designed to generate a measure of underlying risk of conflict, usually produced as a
label: BODY

text: probability of conflict at a certain geographic scale within a certain timeframe.
label: BODY

text: •	 Continuous prediction models are those that directly predict a specific measure of conflict, such as
label: BODY

text: the number of fatalities or conflict events (e.g., 142), without putting the results into a category or
label: BODY

text: scale.
label: BODY

text: By way of example, consider the results from the three types of models if they were designed to predict
label: BODY

text: in December 2021 if there would be fatalities due to state-based violence in Mali in February 2022. For the
label: BODY

text: purposes of classification and risk prediction, conflict is defined as occurring if there are 25 or more conflict-
label: BODY

text: related fatalities in one month in Mali, otherwise that month is classified as peaceful. Examples of potential
label: BODY

text: predictions could be:
label: BODY

text: •	 Classification: There will be conflict.
label: BODY

text: •	 Risk prediction: There is a 75 percent probability of conflict.
label: BODY

text: •	 Continuous prediction: There will be 33 fatalities due to conflict.
label: BODY

text: For interested readers, further details on each of these models are available in the Technical Annex.
label: BODY

text: Each of these methods are used in the humanitarian sector to assess various hazards and shocks, including
label: BODY

text: conflict. OCHA’s anticipatory action frameworks in the Philippines (typhoons), Bangladesh4 (floods) and
label: BODY

text: Somalia/Ethiopia (drought) rely on classification models. While input models of drought,5 floods or other
label: BODY

text: events often produce probabilities of the event happening, classification models set thresholds on the
label: BODY

text: probabilities. For instance, in the Philippines anticipatory action framework, trigger thresholds are set
label: BODY

text: based on the probability of buildings being damaged by a typhoon: if there is over 50 percent probability
label: BODY

text: of 80,000 houses being damaged in a specific geographic area, the threshold is met and anticipatory action
label: BODY

text: is triggered.6 A familiar example of a classification model in the humanitarian sector is the Integrated Food
label: BODY

text: Security Phase Classification (IPC) where the five classes generated are the projected phase of acute food
label: BODY

text: insecurity in a given area, five being the most severe (i.e., famine).7
label: BODY

text: While not calculated directly as a probability, the INFORM Risk Index, meant to measure general risk of crisis
label: BODY

text: for a country based on structural factors, is an example of a risk prediction model.8 INFORM itself uses
label: BODY

text: a conflict risk estimate, the Global Conflict Risk Index, as one of its key inputs.9 The global displacement
label: BODY

text: forecasts produced by the Danish Refugee Council are continuous predictions of the number of displaced
label: BODY

text: persons.10
label: BODY

text: 2.1 MODELS IN THE HUMANITARIAN SECTOR
label: HH1

text: 4    UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 2021. Anticipatory Action Bangladesh.
label: BODY

text: 5    Rogerio Bonifacio, Gabriela Guimaraes Nobre, and Daniela Cuellar, 2021. Drought Forecasting, Thresholds and Triggers: Implementing Forecast-Based
label: BODY

text: Financing in Mozambique. EGU Gen. Assemb. Conf. 21.
label: BODY

text: 6    UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 2022. Anticipatory Action Philippines.
label: BODY

text: 7    Timothy R Frankenberger and René Verduijn, 2011. Integrated Food Security Phase Classification: End of Project Evaluation.
label: BODY

text: 8    The Joint Research Center of European Commission, INFORM - Global, Open-Source Risk Assessment for Humanitarian Crises and Disasters.
label: BODY

text: 9    Matina Kalkia et al., 2022. The Global Conflict Risk Index: A Quantitative Tool for Policy Support on Conflict Prevention, Prog. Disaster Sci. 6, 100069.
label: BODY

text: 10  Danish Refugee Council, 2021. Global Displacement Forecast 2021.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 11  Hannes Mueller and Christopher Rauh, 2022b. Using Past Violence and Current News to Predict Changes in Violence, Int. Interact.
label: BODY

text: 12  Samantha Kuzma et al., 2020. Leveraging Water Data in a Machine Learning–Based Model for Forecasting Violent Conflict, World Resources Institute.
label: BODY

text: 13  Ibid.
label: BODY

text: 14  Markus Enenkel et al., 2020. Why Predict Climate Hazards If We Need to Understand Impacts? Putting Humans Back into the Drought Equation, Clim.
label: BODY

text: 15  International Committee of the Red Cross, 2021. When Rain Turns to Dust.
label: BODY

text: MODEL ASPECTS
label: HH1

text: For these three models types, forecasts of conflict are typically defined by a few parameters:
label: BODY

text: •	 Lead time: How far in advance the model predicts conflict. Lead time can range from one month
label: BODY

text: to often between one and three years, but can go out to 50 years in some of the literature.
label: BODY

text: •	 Length of forecasting period: The temporal range of the forecast period. The length of forecast
label: HH1

text: is typically one month but can go all the way to a ten year period in some models. This is different
label: BODY

text: from lead time, where you could predict conflict in a single month one year into the future.
label: BODY

text: •	 Geographic distribution: The geographic scope of the prediction exercise. Is the model global or
label: HH1

text: applicable only to a specific country or context? Geographic distribution is almost always at the
label: BODY

text: country level or more granular, such as for states or districts within a country.
label: BODY

text: •	 Type: Type of the conflict being predicted, such as state vs. non-state actors.
label: HH1

text: •	 Scale: Scale of the conflict being predicted, often defined in terms of number of deaths. Scale
label: BODY

text: can be used to define whether a conflict is happening or not, but can be more complex, such as
label: BODY

text: by defining no conflict, minor levels of conflict, or major levels of conflict. Scale is only used in
label: BODY

text: classification and risk prediction models; continuous predictions do not use a definition of scale,
label: BODY

text: which is intrinsic to the model itself (i.e., directly predicting the number of deaths).
label: BODY

text: 3. OVERALL PERFORMANCE
label: HH1

text: There are common issues affecting the usability of all three models: the scale of predicted conflict;
label: BODY

text: predicting conflict onset and escalation; and the lack of linkages between predicted conflict and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian impact. The last issue is critically important to the feasibility of applying these models for
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action. (Details on the feasibility of each model are available in the Technical Annex).
label: BODY

text: Models are often predicting conflict defined at a relatively small scale in terms of casualties or fatalities and
label: BODY

text: across a large timeline and a wide geographic area. Academic models can perform well, but the scale can be
label: BODY

text: as small as predicting a single conflict fatality in a given month and country.11 The humanitarian impact of
label: BODY

text: one fatality in a month or 10 conflict deaths in a year in a country12 is not readily derivable from the models.
label: BODY

text: This is also an issue for defining conflict onset, where onset is typically defined as the first time when the
label: BODY

text: scale of conflict used for the model is observed. For instance: the month with 25 battle-related deaths after
label: BODY

text: 24 preceding months without 25 battle-related deaths.13 Even if conflict prediction improved to forecast
label: BODY

text: conflict escalation, it is not clear that this would directly predict the dynamics of humanitarian needs.
label: BODY

text: Predicting the humanitarian impact of a conflict remains a challenge. This is not just an issue for conflict
label: BODY

text: prediction but also for other applications of anticipatory action, such as for climate hazards.14 While there
label: BODY

text: has been some research on this topic,15 the dynamics of conflict and its potential impact on humanitarian
label: BODY

text: needs and response require more investigation, particularly in how foreseeable these impacts are.
label: BODY

text: 3.1 PREDICTED CONFLICT AND HUMANITARIAN IMPACT
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 16  Richard J. Choularton and P. Krishna Krishnamurthy, 2019. How Accurate Is Food Security Early Warning? Evaluation of FEWS NET Accuracy in
label: BODY

text: Ethiopia, Food Sec. 11:2, 333–44.
label: BODY

text: 17  Timothy R Frankenberger and René Verduijn, 2011.
label: BODY

text: 18  Joris J. L. Westerveld et al., 2021. Forecasting Transitions in the State of Food Security with Machine Learning Using Transferable Features, Sci. Total
label: BODY

text: 19  Societies at Risk research programme, Department of Peace and Conflict Research, Uppsala University.
label: BODY

text: 20 OCHA Anticipatory Action.
label: BODY

text: 21   Michael D Ward, Brian D Greenhill, and Kristin M Bakke, 2010. The Perils of Policy by P-Value: Predicting Civil Conflicts, J. Peace Res. 47:4, 363–75.
label: BODY

text: 22  Thomas Bernauer, Tobias Böhmelt, and Vally Koubi, 2012. Environmental Changes and Violent Conflict, Environ. Res. Lett. 7:1, 015601.
label: BODY

text: 23  Courtland Adams et al., 2018. Sampling Bias in Climate–Conflict Research, Nat. Clim. Change 8:3, 200–03.
label: BODY

text: This research could build on existing work in the food insecurity space, where FEWS NET16 and the IPC17
label: BODY

text: work on integrating multiple data sources to project future levels of food insecurity. New models are being
label: BODY

text: explored that can more accurately predict transitions between IPC phases to improve early warning.18 And a
label: BODY

text: new six year research programme into the complex impacts of armed conflict recently began in May 2022.19
label: BODY

text: 4. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE WORK
label: HH1

text: Given our findings, we do not see immediate applications of conflict prediction for triggering anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action. These recommendations do not preclude the application of anticipatory action in response to other
label: BODY

text: shocks in a conflict setting.
label: BODY

text: The following three areas should be considered as potential avenues towards feasibility: 1) adopt modeling
label: BODY

text: best practices; 2) explore areas that are under researched; and 3) practice transparent development and
label: BODY

text: evaluation of models.
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action is typically defined by models with clear thresholds set in an agreed upon, transparent
label: BODY

text: framework.20 Discussed in more detail in the Technical Annex, it is possible that risk prediction models (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: there is 50 percent probability of conflict) perform well, but classification models (e.g., setting a threshold on
label: BODY

text: that probability) do not. However, it is unclear how risk models would be applied in an anticipatory action
label: BODY

text: framework that typically require these explicit thresholds (i.e., the use of a classification model).
label: BODY

text: Risk models are typically utilized for disaster risk reduction, peacekeeping, or security, but may not be
label: BODY

text: immediately applicable to anticipatory action. Additional work is needed to explore if and how it would
label: BODY

text: be possible to use risk or continuous prediction models in anticipatory action if classification models are
label: BODY

text: technically infeasible due to poor performance.
label: BODY

text: 3.2 ANTICIPATORY ACTION WITHOUT THRESHOLDS
label: HH1

text: The modeling and prediction of conflict should learn from the findings generated by the research community
label: BODY

text: in recent years, including using many predictors of conflict in models and using ensemble methods.
label: BODY

text: Include many predictors of conflict in models
label: HH1

text: A vast array of conflict predictors have been identified in the literature but they are often not consistently
label: BODY

text: identified across all models.21 The drivers of conflict vary across the political, socioeconomic and
label: BODY

text: environmental landscape: from contested elections and political shifts to crop failure or unemployment.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, a literature review on the impact of environmental changes on conflict found that there was
label: BODY

text: still no consensus on the relationship between the two phenomena. Findings are often not robust to changes
label: BODY

text: in the model (e.g., a claim may be based on a particular model, but adding new indicators invalidates the
label: BODY

text: claim) and identified relationships between predictors and conflict may not be systematic across crises.22
label: BODY

text: Similar issues have been identified in the literature when linking climate change to conflict, where the
label: BODY

text: evidence may not be as strong as assumed.23
label: BODY

text: 4.1 ADOPT MODELING BEST PRACTICES
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: To avoid these kinds of errors, the use of predictive models to validate causal frameworks has been
label: BODY

text: increasingly common in the literature, such as testing how well measures of democratic governance predict
label: BODY

text: a country’s willingness to engage in conflict.24, 25, 26 The purpose is to justify the importance of a causal factor,
label: BODY

text: such as democratic governance, climate shifts or elections, based on how well they help the model predict
label: BODY

text: future conflict rather than through statistical inference. Research has found that models focused on a
label: BODY

text: particular driver or theoretical framework for conflict causality often have subpar performance.27
label: BODY

text: New work on conflict prediction in the humanitarian sector should recognize conflict as a multi-dimensional
label: BODY

text: problem. These efforts should not spend significant time or resources on developing strict theoretical
label: BODY

text: frameworks for conflict causality or focus on a single driver, such as the lack of water, that may not prove
label: BODY

text: fruitful if validated based on predictive performance. These efforts can be extremely valuable in many
label: BODY

text: applications, but have not proven effective for the specific task of predicting conflict.
label: BODY

text: Consider ensemble methods
label: HH1

text: In a similar vein, ensemble methods such as random forests,28 Bayesian model averaging,29 and gradient
label: BODY

text: boosting machines30 tend to outperform single model specifications in predictive performance. State-of-
label: BODY

text: the-art academic research on conflict prediction focuses almost exclusively on ensemble models. This
label: BODY

text: approach is common in modeling for other complex processes, such as climate.31 Future exploratory work in
label: BODY

text: the humanitarian sector should take this into account, particularly when single model specifications might
label: BODY

text: require a lot of time spent on fine tuning and may fail to learn different features of the data in ways that
label: BODY

text: ensemble models can.
label: BODY

text: 24  Michael Ward et al., 2013. Learning from the Past and Stepping into the Future: Toward a New Generation of Conflict Prediction, Int. Stud. Rev. 15, 473–90.
label: BODY

text: 25  Michael D. Ward, Randolph M. Siverson, and Xun Cao, 2007. Disputes, Democracies, and Dependencies: A Reexamination of the Kantian Peace, Am. J.
label: BODY

text: Political Sci. 51:3, 583–601.
label: BODY

text: 26  Vito D’Orazio, 2020. Conflict Forecasting and Prediction, Oxford Research Encyclopedia of International Studies.
label: BODY

text: 27  Nathaniel Beck, Gary King, and Langche Zeng, 2000. Improving Quantitative Studies of International Conflict: A Conjecture, Am. Political Sci. Rev.
label: BODY

text: 94:1, 21–35; Andreas Beger, Richard K. Morgan, and Michael D. Ward, 2021. Reassessing the Role of Theory and Machine Learning in Forecasting Civil
label: BODY

text: Conflict, J. Conflict Resolut. 65: 7–8, 1405–26.
label: BODY

text: 28  Samantha Kuzma et al., 2020.
label: BODY

text: 29 Jacob M. Montgomery, Florian M. Hollenbach, and Michael D. Ward, 2012. Improving Predictions Using Ensemble Bayesian Model Averaging, Polit.
label: BODY

text: 30 Jonas Vestby et al., 2022. Predicting (de-)Escalation of Sub-National Violence Using Gradient Boosting: Does It Work?, Int. Interact.
label: BODY

text: 31   Climate Information, Why use a model ensemble?
label: BODY

text: 32  Joyce E. Berg, Forrest D. Nelson, and Thomas A. Rietz, 2008. Prediction Market Accuracy in the Long Run, Int. J. Forecast. 24:2, 285–300
label: BODY

text: 33  Philip E. Tetlock, Barbara A. Mellers, and J. Peter Scoblic, 2017. Bringing Probability Judgments into Policy Debates via Forecasting Tournaments,
label: BODY

text: 34  Thomas Chadefaux, 2017. Conflict Forecasting and Its Limits, Data Sci. 1:1–2, 7–17.
label: BODY

text: Based on our review of the literature, we recommend future endeavors focus on areas that have yet to be
label: BODY

text: fully explored by the research community. This includes utilizing superforecasters and prediction markets;
label: BODY

text: incorporating local data and analysis; predicting shifts in conflict; predicting risks, not events; and predicting
label: BODY

text: the impact of conflict. As explained above, it is unlikely that a single type of model or approach will work
label: BODY

text: across all conflicts relevant to humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: Utilize superforecasters and prediction markets
label: HH1

text: The use of human inputs for prediction, such as superforecasters, prediction tournaments, or markets have
label: BODY

text: been shown to outperform purely quantitative approaches in certain predictive tasks, such as election
label: BODY

text: outcome predictions across a long time horizon.32 This approach can generate knowledge for policy
label: BODY

text: decisions even when quantitative modeling might not be possible or has limited performance.33 Humans
label: BODY

text: can identify  difficult to discern patterns or unmeasurable quantities that machine learning algorithms can
label: BODY

text: miss. Similarly, shifting dynamics of state borders, geopolitics and other predictors are difficult to capture
label: BODY

text: quantitatively. The utility of purely quantitative predictions of conflict remains an open question.34
label: BODY

text: 4.2 EXPLORE AREAS THAT ARE UNDER RESEARCHED
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: Extensive time and resources are required to manage a human forecasting network over a sufficient period
label: BODY

text: of time for model development, testing and use.35 These methods are not frequently found in the research
label: BODY

text: community, and most examples have been generated from communities less likely to publish rigorous
label: BODY

text: validations. This includes the intelligence and defense communities, community or crowd-sourced early
label: BODY

text: warning systems, and conflict monitoring mechanisms. Some results have been promising,36 although the
label: BODY

text: findings have been questioned.37 When trying this approach, models could use only human inputs without
label: BODY

text: any additional quantitative data, or human inputs could be utilized as additional predictors alongside other
label: BODY

text: quantitative data.
label: BODY

text: Incorporate local data and analysis
label: HH1

text: Socioeconomic, political and other input data for conflict prediction are often missing or insufficient,
label: BODY

text: particularly in the most fragile and conflict-affected states. In order to predict conflict, it is required to fill in
label: BODY

text: these missing inputs. This work is sometimes done directly by conflict modelers38 or by implicitly relying on
label: BODY

text: modeled data, such as World Bank poverty headcounts or the INFORM Risk Index.39 The use of these proxies
label: BODY

text: presents issues for detecting rapid shifts in conflict dynamics. In addition, the poorer quality of the data,
label: BODY

text: compared with directly measured variables, likely limits the overall forecasting potential of quantitative
label: BODY

text: models.40
label: BODY

text: Prediction of conflict at the subnational level is typically done by disaggregating data across subnational
label: BODY

text: boundaries41 or using a grid approach (e.g., predicting conflict within a 55km area).42 While data available
label: BODY

text: globally can be subnational, using locally captured data may be more sensitive to dynamic shifts that best
label: BODY

text: predict conflict.
label: BODY

text: There is also a potential to develop models that predict where conflict will occur,43 or hotspots of higher
label: BODY

text: risk,44 rather than when.45 This may be more feasible and still useful for humanitarian operations. However,
label: BODY

text: it should be recognized that even where local data is available, model performance is often still too poor for
label: BODY

text: operationalization and extensive testing remains a baseline requirement.46 While these models may improve
label: BODY

text: performance to specific contexts, they will also be much more difficult to generalize to a regional or global
label: BODY

text: level.
label: BODY

text: Predict conflict shifts
label: HH1

text: Recent academic research has begun to focus on predicting the probability of conflict cessation or onset.47
label: BODY

text: This requires a more nuanced set of error metrics and validation for models that might underperform more
label: BODY

text: broadly in predicting conflict but better capture conflict escalations. A recent conflict escalation prediction
label: BODY

text: competition hosted by ViEWS has produced a set of metrics useful for assessing continuous predictions.48
label: BODY

text: New developments should focus on linking this work to classification models and assessing their
label: BODY

text: performance in predicting large scale conflict onset or escalation that is more directly useful in anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action for humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: This will require the identification and use of time-variant predictors that can go beyond estimating the
label: BODY

text: underlying risk of conflict to better measure when risks are changing due to dynamic factors, and may
label: BODY

text: require the use of more localized or human inputs to prove successful.
label: BODY

text: 35  Michael C. Horowitz, Julia Ciocca, and Lauren Kahn, 2021. Keeping Score: A New Approach to Geopolitical Forecasting, Perry World House.
label: BODY

text: 36  Bradley J. Stastny and Paul E. Lehner, 2018. Comparative Evaluation of the Forecast Accuracy of Analysis Reports and a Prediction Market, Judgm. Decis.
label: BODY

text: 37  David R Mandel, 2018. Too Soon to Tell If the US Intelligence Community Prediction Market Is More Accurate than Intelligence Reports: Commentary on
label: BODY

text: Stastny and Lehner, Judgm. Decis. Mak. 14:3, 288.
label: BODY

text: 38  Håvard Hegre et al., 2019. ViEWS: A Political Violence Early-Warning System, J. Peace Res. 56:2, 155–74.
label: BODY

text: 39  Samantha Kuzma et al., 2020.
label: BODY

text: 40 Lars-Erik Cederman and Nils B. Weidmann, 2017.
label: BODY

text: 41  Siri Camilla Aas Rustad et al., 2011. All Conflict Is Local: Modeling Sub-National Variation in Civil Conflict Risk, Confl. Manag. Peace Sci. 28:1, 15–40.
label: BODY

text: 42 Håvard Hegre et al., 2022.
label: BODY

text: 43 Sebastian Schutte, 2017. Regions at Risk: Predicting Conflict Zones in African Insurgencies, Political Sci. Res. Methods 5:3, 447–65.
label: BODY

text: 44 May Lim, Richard Metzler, and Yaneer Bar-Yam, 2007. Global Pattern Formation and Ethnic/Cultural Violence, Science 317:5844, 1540–44.
label: BODY

text: 45 Siri Camilla Aas Rustad et al., 2011.
label: BODY

text: 46 Samuel Bazzi et al., 2022. The Promise and Pitfalls of Conﬂict Prediction: Evidence from Colombia and Indonesia, Rev. Econ. Stat. 104:4, 764–79.
label: BODY

text: 47 Samantha Kuzma et al., 2020; Jonas Vestby et al., 2022.
label: BODY

text: 48 Paola Vesco et al., 2022. United They Stand: Findings from an Escalation Prediction Competition, Int. Interact.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: Predict risk, not events
label: HH1

text: Although we do not preclude the possibility that classification models become feasible for application in
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action in the future, we recommend focusing on risk prediction models. The use of human
label: BODY

text: forecasters, agent-based modeling and simulation,50 or even scenario building,51 could be used to improve
label: BODY

text: upon and develop conflict risk models. Answering the open questions around probabilistic risk prediction
label: BODY

text: is likely simpler than improving the performance of classification. Risk models may have good performance
label: BODY

text: and if well-calibrated would present valuable information for use in humanitarian response, although how to
label: BODY

text: apply it for anticipatory action remains unclear.
label: BODY

text: Predict the impact of conflict
label: HH1

text: In response to the war in Ukraine, predictions have proliferated on the impact of the crisis on global food
label: BODY

text: insecurity due to a number of factors, including disruption of agricultural production in the region, disruption
label: BODY

text: to supply chains due to sanctions, and reduced funding for other crises.51 The current intensity and interstate
label: BODY

text: nature of the Ukraine conflict make it a relatively unique context for generating predictions.
label: BODY

text: However, this is not always the case and it is therefore a critical area for further research. The humanitarian
label: BODY

text: impacts of conflict, depending on its type, scale and many other factors, are extremely diffuse. Meaningful
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action on conflict would require not just the prediction of conflict events or risk, but also an
label: BODY

text: ability to extend that prediction to the humanitarian impact of the conflict. Only by knowing the impact could
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action be effective in reducing vulnerability. Understanding the relationship between conflict
label: BODY

text: and humanitarian impact is therefore critical for understanding how to set the parameters for any model:
label: BODY

text: defining conflict onset or escalation or the type of conflict to predict relies on how linked these elements are
label: BODY

text: to humanitarian impact.
label: BODY

text: To better link predictions of conflict to humanitarian impact, we should explore, among other things, the use
label: BODY

text: of more locally generated data, the incorporation of human judgment, and alternative modeling techniques
label: BODY

text: to make models more sensitive to dynamics on the ground.
label: BODY

text: 50 Marina Andrijevic et al., 2020. Governance in Socioeconomic Pathways and Its Role for Future Adaptive Capacity, Nat. Sustain. 3:1, 35–41.
label: BODY

text: 51  World Food Programme, 2022. Food Security Implications of the Ukraine Conflict; Food and Agriculture Organization, 2022. Note on the Impact of the War
label: BODY

text: on Food Security in Ukraine.
label: BODY

text: 52  Dan Maxwell et al., 2021. Seeing in the Dark: Real-Time Monitoring in Humanitarian Crises, Tufts Feinstein International Center.
label: BODY

text: 53  Philip E. Tetlock, Barbara A. Mellers, and J. Peter Scoblic, 2017.
label: BODY

text: While some of the methods described above have been implemented, there is often a lack of clear and
label: BODY

text: transparent testing and publication of model performance, including through the use of peer review
label: BODY

text: processes. All conflict prediction research, development and implementation should use transparent and
label: BODY

text: reproducible methods that clearly communicate their performance. Open communication efforts are critical
label: BODY

text: to building trust in complex models and are a prerequisite for achieving feasibility.
label: BODY

text: Transparency should not be restricted to the development of quantitative modeling. All conflict prediction
label: BODY

text: exercises, even human forecast-based methods, should strive to test and validate approaches. Validation will
label: BODY

text: allow end users to assign credibility to high performing models and recognize where further improvements
label: BODY

text: are needed prior to implementation.53 Although beyond the scope of this paper, ethical review of models and
label: BODY

text: their applications is also critical given the sensitivities of conflict-related programming.
label: BODY

text: 4.3 PRACTICE TRANSPARENT DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION OF MODELS
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 54  Marie Wagner and Catalina Jaime, 2020.
label: BODY

text: 55  Hannes Mueller and Christopher Rauh, 2022b.
label: BODY

text: 5. CONCLUSION
label: HH1

text: Based on the review of the current literature, we return to the original questions54 framing our research.
label: BODY

text: How accurate are conflict forecasts?
label: BODY

text: For classification models, the current evidence shows that model performance, particularly when predicting
label: BODY

text: conflict onset or benchmarked against a simple model using conflict history, is not sufficient for application
label: BODY

text: in humanitarian response. This is in addition to the missing link between predicted conflict and humanitarian
label: BODY

text: impact.
label: BODY

text: Risk and continuous prediction modeling requires additional evidence on how accurate risk estimates
label: BODY

text: correspond to observed risk for responsible implementation and adoption. However, their applications in
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action are less clear due to the lack of thresholds, which are required to automate the release of
label: BODY

text: funds.
label: BODY

text: How well can various sources predict different types of conflict in specific situations?
label: BODY

text: For the purpose of this paper, we mainly focused on the overall performance of conflict prediction models
label: BODY

text: rather than the predictive power of various sources. However, it is clear that conflict history is the best
label: BODY

text: predictor of future conflict but its utility is limited to ongoing conflicts. While some sources can improve
label: BODY

text: model performance, the best performing models are often those that use the widest range of available
label: BODY

text: data. But critically, these models often predict conflict at a scale too small for meaningful application in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response, and do not significantly outperform simple models solely built on conflict history.55
label: BODY

text: We therefore conclude that the current set of classification models in use or under development do not have
label: BODY

text: sufficient predictive performance for anticipatory action. The feasibility of application for risk and continuous
label: BODY

text: models remains an open question that requires further research.
label: BODY

text: To make use of conflict prediction for anticipatory action in the humanitarian sector, we recommend to focus
label: BODY

text: on six areas.
label: BODY

text: Utilize flexible models that do not pre-suppose a theoretical framework of conflict causality. Future
label: HH1

text: work on developing conflict prediction models should build on the current literature. The most fruitful
label: BODY

text: areas of exploration will likely be found using ensemble models or non-linear techniques that require little
label: BODY

text: theoretical knowledge and the use of as many input predictors as available.
label: BODY

text: Focus models on predicting shifts in conflicts, such as an increase in intensity or onset. This could
label: BODY

text: help transition the usefulness of conflict prediction from use in preparedness and disaster risk reduction to
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action, where acting prior to a new or intensifying shock is the point.
label: BODY

text: Explore the use of human inputs through superforecasters or prediction markets and use local data
label: HH1

text: to improve model performance in specific contexts. Work should be done to include and validate the
label: HH1

text: usefulness of human inputs into model frameworks, such as through superforecasters or prediction markets.
label: BODY

text: Models can be validated and tested against their ability to predict the timing of specific events or conflict
label: BODY

text: shifts.
label: BODY

text: 5.1 RECOMMENDATIONS AND NEXT STEPS
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 56 Joris J. L. Westerveld et al., 2021.
label: BODY

text: 57  The Joint Research Center of European Commission, INFORM - Global, Open-Source Risk Assessment for Humanitarian Crises and Disasters.
label: BODY

text: 58 Danish Refugee Council, 2021; Christopher Earney and Rebeca Moreno Jimenez, 2019. Pioneering Predictive Analytics for Decision-Making in Forced
label: BODY

text: Displacement Contexts, Guide to Mobile Data Analytics in Refugee Scenarios: The ‘Data for Refugees Challenge’ Study, 101–19.
label: BODY

text: 59 Kevin Hernandez and Tony Roberts, 2020. Predictive Analytics in Humanitarian Action: A Preliminary Mapping and Analysis, Institute of Development
label: BODY

text: Studies.
label: BODY

text: 60 Sarah Bressan, 2021. Crisis Early Warning: Berlin’s Path From Foresight to Prevention, Peace Lab; Predicting Conflict – a Year in Advance, The Alan Turing
label: BODY

text: Institute.
label: BODY

text: 61  Håvard Hegre et al., 2022.
label: BODY

text: 62 Laura Hielkema and Jasmijn Suidman, 2021. Multi-Hazard Risk Analysis Methodologies, Anticipation Hub.
label: BODY

text: Improve predictions on the humanitarian impact of conflict as opposed to conflict itself. Work on
label: HH1

text: predicting the humanitarian impact of conflict should be prioritized. Understanding the relationship
label: BODY

text: between humanitarian needs and conflict is necessary for any predictions to be acted on. Even without
label: BODY

text: predicting the onset or escalation of a conflict, improvements in predicting the humanitarian impacts of
label: BODY

text: conflict could potentially enable anticipatory action on the impacts of observed conflict. This work could be
label: BODY

text: undertaken through better integration of conflict data and modeling with existing forecasting systems, which
label: BODY

text: is already being explored for predicting food insecurity.56
label: BODY

text: Ensure that model development and evaluation is done in a reproducible and transparent way that
label: HH1

text: highlights the model performance in all relevant metrics. Humanitarian work on measuring risk,57
label: HH1

text: predicting displacement,58 and other applications of predictive analytics59 often do not communicate
label: BODY

text: validation statistics and evidence of good performance. Recent efforts by governments60 and academics
label: BODY

text: to predict conflict for use in humanitarian response61 also fail to show performance sufficient to what is
label: BODY

text: required for use in decision making. Regardless of the approach or methodology,62 it is critical that all
label: BODY

text: models are transparent and that their performance is validated.
label: BODY

text: Learn from the state-of-the-art research underway in the academic field and ensure that applied
label: HH1

text: research is relevant for humanitarian decision making. Significant time and resources will be required to
label: HH1

text: collect data, develop models and test performance of new observations, particularly if models are extended
label: BODY

text: to predict humanitarian impact. It is only through engagement between conflict researchers, academia, the
label: BODY

text: private sector and the humanitarian community that this work will be sustainably financed and developed.
label: BODY

text: We hope that the above recommendations provide an initial framework and understanding for these
label: BODY

text: conversations. We welcome questions and feedback at centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 63  The ViEWS team, 2021. The Risk Monitor: December 2021.
label: BODY

text: 64  Conflict Forecast system, for example.
label: BODY

text: 65  Frank DW Witmer et al., 2017. Subnational Violent Conflict Forecasts for Sub-Saharan Africa, 2015–65, Using Climate-Sensitive Models, J. Peace Res. 54:2,
label: BODY

text: 175–92; Benjamin E. Bagozzi, 2015. Forecasting Civil Conflict with Zero-Inflated Count Models, Civil Wars 17:1, 1–24; N. Johnson et al., 2018. Self-Exciting Point
label: BODY

text: Process Models for Political Conflict Forecasting, Eur. J. Appl. Math. 29:4, 685–707.
label: BODY

text: TECHNICAL ANNEX
label: HH1

text: As described in the body of this paper, the three model types are:
label: BODY

text: •	 Classification: There will be conflict.
label: BODY

text: •	 Risk prediction: There is a 75 percent probability of conflict.
label: BODY

text: •	 Continuous prediction: There will be 33 fatalities due to conflict.
label: BODY

text: We describe each model and assess their usefulness and performance in more detail below.
label: BODY

text: 1. TYPES OF PREDICTION
label: HH1

text: Classification models categorically state whether or not a conflict will occur in a particular area and time,
label: BODY

text: through either binary (yes/no) or multiclass classification (e.g., major, minor or no conflict, or a 1-5 scale).
label: BODY

text: For binary models, the classifications are whether or not conflict will or will not occur in that single time
label: BODY

text: period, which may or may not be different from the previous period (e.g., predicting peace in one period but
label: BODY

text: conflict in the next).
label: BODY

text: Classification models are typically built on top of a probabilistic model. Thresholds are then determined that
label: BODY

text: convert the probability of conflict into discrete classes, such as by predicting that conflict will only occur if
label: BODY

text: the probability is greater than a specific value. For instance, recall the Mali example where conflict is defined
label: BODY

text: as occurring if there are 25 or more conflict-related fatalities in one month. Using a probability threshold of
label: BODY

text: 50 percent, a risk estimate of 75 percent would result in a classification forecast that conflict will occur in
label: BODY

text: February 2022 resulting in 25 or more fatalities.
label: BODY

text: 1.1 CLASSIFICATION
label: HH1

text: Risk prediction is designed to generate a measure of underlying risk of conflict, usually produced as
label: BODY

text: a probability of conflict at a certain geographic scale within a certain timeframe. These are often the
label: BODY

text: probabilistic models that underlie classification models.
label: BODY

text: Predictions are typically generated from a set of indicators, e.g., gross domestic product or number of
label: BODY

text: conflict events, that are fed into the model. The probabilities typically range from near zero percent in
label: BODY

text: contexts that have not seen conflict in years to close to 100 percent in active conflict zones. Examples of this
label: BODY

text: type of model are the ViEWS Risk Monitor63 and related conflict forecasting systems,64 which usually publish
label: BODY

text: forecasts as risk predictions. For instance, in the December 2021 ViEWS Risk Monitor, the risk of state-based
label: BODY

text: violence resulting in 25 or more fatalities in Mali by February 2022 was estimated to be greater than 75
label: BODY

text: percent.
label: BODY

text: 1.2 RISK PREDICTION
label: HH1

text: Continuous prediction models are those that predict a specific measure of conflict, such as the number of
label: BODY

text: fatalities or conflict events.65 Since these models do not define conflict thresholds, they are potentially better
label: BODY

text: able to capture gradations in severity and magnitude that may be missed in risk prediction or classification.
label: BODY

text: In the case of Mali, the continuous prediction for February 2022 could be an exact figure of 33 fatalities.
label: BODY

text: 1.3 CONTINUOUS PREDICTION
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 66  Colin G. Walsh, Kavya Sharman, and George Hripcsak, 2017. Beyond Discrimination: A Comparison of Calibration Methods and Clinical Usefulness of
label: BODY

text: Predictive Models of Readmission Risk, J. Biomed. Inform. 76, 9–18.
label: BODY

text: 67 R. B. D’Agostino and Byung-Ho Nam, 2003. Evaluation of the Performance of Survival Analysis Models: Discrimination and Calibration Measures, Handb.
label: BODY

text: 68 Tilmann Gneiting and Adrian E Raftery, 2007. Strictly Proper Scoring Rules, Prediction, and Estimation, J. Am. Stat. Assoc. 102:477, 359–78.
label: BODY

text: 69 A. Donati et al., 2004. A New and Feasible Model for Predicting Operative Risk, Br. J. Anaesth. 93:3, 393–99.
label: BODY

text: Classification outputs are often more useful to policy makers due to their ease of interpretation and
label: BODY

text: actionability, but may not always be preferable to other models based on measures of predictive
label: BODY

text: performance. For example, imagine a model that generates probabilities of conflict with the prediction
label: BODY

text: based on a specific threshold. Predictions greater than or equal to the threshold will be predicted as being in
label: BODY

text: conflict, and those below as not in conflict. This requires decent separability of the data, which means that
label: BODY

text: the threshold clearly delineates when conflict will occur versus when it will not. If that is the case, there is
label: BODY

text: high confidence that conflict will occur if the threshold is met.
label: BODY

text: Conversely, risk prediction models can be used even if we do not have the confidence in predicting a specific
label: BODY

text: event. Intuitively, when a risk model predicts a 50 percent probability of conflict, the model performs well
label: BODY

text: if conflict occurs approximately 50 percent of the time. However, a threshold of 50 percent for classification
label: BODY

text: would generate false positives 50 percent of the time.
label: BODY

text: 1.4 MODEL USEFULNESS
label: HH1

text: There are a variety of metrics used to assess model performance. The main difference is between measuring
label: BODY

text: calibration or discrimination.
label: BODY

text: Calibration is how well the probabilities of a model match observed frequencies. Perfect calibration means
label: HH1

text: if we predict a 50 percent probability of conflict, it is likely to occur 50 percent of the time.66 Poor calibration
label: BODY

text: means that the predicted probability is not representative of the actual likelihood of conflict.
label: BODY

text: Discrimination is how well the model is able to separate two or more classifications (e.g., conflict and no
label: BODY

text: conflict) in the data using a specific threshold. If there was a threshold of 50 percent probability of conflict,
label: BODY

text: perfect discrimination would be that there is always conflict if the probability is higher than 50 percent, and
label: BODY

text: never conflict if the probability is lower. Poor discrimination could be where conflict is just as likely to occur
label: BODY

text: whether or not the prediction is above the threshold.
label: BODY

text: Models can be well-calibrated even when they have poor discrimination (and vice-versa).67
label: BODY

text: 2. MODEL PERFORMANCE
label: HH1

text: MODEL PERFORMANCE METRICS
label: HH1

text: Measures of calibration for classification and risk prediction models include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Brier score: Measures how close predicted probabilities of conflict are to the observed truth.
label: BODY

text: •	 Continuous risk probability score (CRPS): Measures the accuracy of probabilistic forecasts
label: BODY

text: against the observed distribution of outcomes.68
label: BODY

text: •	 Hosmer-Lemeshow test: Measures how closely the predicted probabilities match the observed
label: BODY

text: occurrence of events.69
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 70 Michael Ward et al., 2013.
label: BODY

text: 71  Clionadh Raleigh et al., 2010. Introducing ACLED: An Armed Conflict Location and Event Dataset: Special Data Feature, J.Peace Res. 47:5, 651–60.
label: BODY

text: 72  Ralph Sundberg and Erik Melander, 2013. Introducing the UCDP Georeferenced Event Dataset, J. Peace Res. 50:4, 523–32.
label: BODY

text: 73  Deborah J. Gerner, Philip A. Schrodt, and Ömür Yilmaz, 2008. Conflict and Mediation Event Observations (CAMEO): An Event Data Framework for a
label: BODY

text: Post-Cold War World, International Conflict Mediation, 287–304.
label: BODY

text: 74  Patrick T. Brandt et al., 2022. Conflict Forecasting with Event Data and Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional Networks, Int. Interact.
label: BODY

text: 75  Nathaniel Beck, Gary King, and Langche Zeng, 2000.
label: BODY

text: Measures of discrimination for classification and risk prediction models include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (ROC AUC): The ability of the model to
label: BODY

text: separate conflict events from non-conflict events at each potential probability threshold.
label: BODY

text: •	 Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve (AUPRC): Measure of the balance between precision and
label: BODY

text: recall that does not use true negatives in its calculation. This makes it potentially important for
label: BODY

text: conflict prediction to ensure that model evaluation is not solely driven by true predictions of ‘no
label: BODY

text: conflict’.
label: BODY

text: •	 Precision: The ability of the model to only predict true conflicts. Only applicable to classification
label: BODY

text: models with set thresholds.
label: BODY

text: •	 Recall: The ability of the model to predict all conflicts. Only applicable to classification models
label: BODY

text: with set thresholds.
label: BODY

text: •	 F1: Balanced measure of the model based on precision and recall. Only applicable to
label: BODY

text: classification models with set thresholds.
label: BODY

text: Metrics for continuous prediction models include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Mean Squared Error (MSE): Common and simple measure of how close the predicted value is to
label: BODY

text: the observed value.
label: BODY

text: •	 Pseudo-Earth Mover Divergence (pEMDiv): A more complex measure that ensures that
label: BODY

text: predictions that are only slightly off geographically or temporally are still slightly rewarded,
label: BODY

text: rather than static accuracy measured for each prediction only against observations in that
label: BODY

text: exact location and point in time.
label: BODY

text: •	 Targeted Absolute Difference with Direction Augmentation (TADDA): Relevant for predictions
label: BODY

text: of change but not point predictions. It is a measure of general accuracy that provides an
label: BODY

text: additional penalty if the predicted direction of change is incorrect.
label: BODY

text: The performance of classification models is typically assessed in the literature by a few key metrics and are
label: BODY

text: calculated on the actual outcomes (e.g., conflict did or did not occur compared to the prediction). Taken
label: BODY

text: together, they give a sense of a model’s usefulness and how it should or should not be applied.
label: BODY

text: Advancements in model performance
label: HH1

text: Over the past two decades, the academic research around conflict prediction has vastly expanded, and
label: BODY

text: overall, model performance has improved.70 These improvements have come on the back of developments
label: BODY

text: in improving global databases of conflict, such as ACLED,71 the UCDP events database,72 or CAMEO event
label: BODY

text: data,73 which provide easier access to data for model development. New techniques for non-linear learning
label: BODY

text: of complex data, such as tree-based models, random forests, and neural networks, have allowed a more
label: BODY

text: complex use of predictor variables without presupposing a theoretical framework for conflict causality,
label: BODY

text: producing more powerful and robust predictions.74, 75
label: BODY

text: 2.1 PERFORMANCE OF CLASSIFICATION MODELS
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 76  Håvard Hegre et al., 2021.
label: BODY

text: 77  Samantha Kuzma et al., 2020.
label: BODY

text: 78  Vito D’Orazio and Yu Lin, 2022. Forecasting Conflict in Africa with Automated Machine Learning Systems, Int. Interact.; Vito D’Orazio et al., 2019. Modeling
label: BODY

text: and Forecasting Armed Conflict: AutoML with Human-Guided Machine Learning, 2019 Int. Conf. Big Data, 4714–23.
label: BODY

text: 79 Samantha Kuzma et al., 2020.
label: BODY

text: 80 Ibid.
label: BODY

text: 81  Iris Malone, 2022. Recurrent Neural Networks for Conflict Forecasting, Int. Interact.
label: BODY

text: Results in the past few years have seen increased predictive performance, with new iterations of the ViEWS
label: BODY

text: models released,76 specific contextual models developed and benchmarked against ViEWS,77 and automated
label: BODY

text: machine learning models outperforming these baselines.78
label: BODY

text: Predictive power of conflict history
label: HH1

text: While these advances have been driven by the development of complex methodologies, much of the
label: BODY

text: predictive power of these models is based on a history of conflict. Where reported in the literature, models
label: BODY

text: with additional predictors often fail to significantly outperform simple models that just use ongoing conflict
label: BODY

text: to predict future conflict.
label: BODY

text: Above, we can see that a simple model, built solely using only ongoing conflict, outperforms the complex
label: BODY

text: model in certain key metrics, in particular AUPR, a robust statistic for rare-event classification, and the Brier
label: BODY

text: score, a key forecast loss statistics.80 New research on deep learning models trained solely on historical
label: BODY

text: conflict data show the capacity of models only relying on conflict history to outperform those with more
label: BODY

text: complex inputs.81
label: BODY

text: These findings highlight two points on the state of conflict prediction:
label: BODY

text: 1. Much of the performance seen in model evaluations is based on predicting no change in the state of
label: BODY

text: conflict, simply a continuation of peace or conflict seen in the previous time period.
label: BODY

text: 2. Until complex models significantly outperform ongoing conflict as a predictor, allocating resources based
label: BODY

text: on where conflict is already occurring would more efficiently reach current and future affected
label: BODY

text: populations than allocating based on complex models.
label: BODY

text: Difficulty in predicting conflict onset
label: HH1

text: There is a distinction between predicting whether conflict is going to continue in its current state (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: classifying the forecasted period to be the same as the current period) and predicting the onset of a conflict
label: BODY

text: where there has not been one previously (e.g., predicting a change in classification between two periods).
label: BODY

text: Water, Peace and Security model underperformed a simple model
label: BODY

text: on key metrics such as AUPR and Brier score79
label: BODY

text: When reported, the performance of models evaluated against onset prediction is relatively poor,82 including
label: BODY

text: older models re-evaluated against new historical data,83 new models built on text data (e.g., newspaper
label: BODY

text: reports)84 and newer research that calculates these benchmarks by default.85 These difficulties are seen
label: BODY

text: across related disciplines, from forecasting genocide86 to political instability and coups.87
label: BODY

text: The figure above plots the precision and recall of a model at all potential probability thresholds, where
label: BODY

text: values to the top of the plot have better precision and to the right of the plot better recall. We can see the
label: BODY

text: significant drop in performance when predicting the onset of conflict (dotted lines) compared to predicting
label: BODY

text: all incidents of conflict (solid lines). This problem also applies when predicting changes in the level of
label: BODY

text: conflict.
label: BODY

text: Efficacy of classification models in predicting conflict
label: HH1

text: Overall, the evidence from the literature shows that classification models lack the performance and
label: BODY

text: granularity needed for anticipatory action. Given the high levels of humanitarian need driven by ongoing
label: BODY

text: conflict and the dominance of ongoing conflict in predicting future conflict, responding to current needs
label: BODY

text: would reach populations most likely to experience the impacts of future conflict. This is different from other
label: BODY

text: shocks, such as flooding, where you cannot anticipate future flooding simply by looking at current flooding.
label: BODY

text: Given the poor performance in predicting the onset of new conflicts or intensification of ongoing
label: BODY

text: conflict, there is little justification for using classification models to drive anticipatory action on conflict.
label: BODY

text: Improvements in conflict prediction are needed for these methods to become operational.
label: BODY

text: Difference in performance, predicting all conflict versus predicting onset88
label: BODY

text: Assessing the feasibility of risk prediction is a separate question from the feasibility of classification. Risk
label: BODY

text: prediction requires the predicted probability of conflict to closely match the observed frequency, (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: calibration described in the above methods section).
label: BODY

text: 2.2 PERFORMANCE OF RISK PREDICTION
label: HH1

text: Lack of validation on calibration
label: HH1

text: Many classification models actually present their results as estimates of conflict risk.89 Yet, the model
label: BODY

text: validation and testing often use metrics designed to test how well the model discriminates between when
label: BODY

text: conflict will or will not occur.90 These measurements of error do not inform the direct usefulness of the
label: BODY

text: probability itself, which requires testing the calibration of the model as described on page fourteen.
label: BODY

text: Proving the performance of risk models requires model validation on its calibration to gauge how well
label: BODY

text: predicted probabilities perform relative to observed distributions.91 These critical prerequisites for the
label: BODY

text: responsible adoption of risk modeling for conflict are not always presented in the conflict forecasting
label: BODY

text: literature, which is often focused on the larger goal of predicting exactly when conflict will occur (and
label: BODY

text: thus relies on measures of discrimination). Although measures of calibration such as the Brier score are
label: BODY

text: frequently used, they are not explored in the same detail as measures of discrimination, with limited plotting
label: BODY

text: of metrics or additional measures presented. Having these readily available would provide more evidence
label: BODY

text: on how the risk probability measures match empirically observed risk and allow end users to interpret and
label: BODY

text: apply the probabilities in planning humanitarian operations.
label: BODY

text: As with classification models, we propose there should also be evidence that risk estimates perform
label: BODY

text: well when predicting the risk of conflict onset, not just in existing conflict scenarios. Applications of risk
label: BODY

text: models should also take into account the model limitations when extending predictions of conflict risk to
label: BODY

text: humanitarian risk, given the scale of conflict and the lack of clear linkages to the risk of humanitarian need
label: BODY

text: that anticipatory action responds to. This may indicate a need for measuring the calibration of models when
label: BODY

text: predicting large-scale escalation or onset, where the scale and potential humanitarian impact are higher, a
label: BODY

text: method being explored for forecasts of food security.92
label: BODY

text: Efficacy of risk models in predicting conflict
label: HH1

text: Unlike the evidence around classification models, there is often a lack of sufficient exploration of model
label: BODY

text: calibration and the performance of conflict risk estimates relative to observed risk. To determine feasibility
label: BODY

text: of application to anticipatory action, measures of risk estimate performance from other fields, such as
label: BODY

text: the Hosmer-Lemeshow test and calibration plots, should be used. Validating how well-calibrated risk
label: BODY

text: prediction models are is a prerequisite for determining feasibility alongside connecting conflict risk to risk of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian impact.
label: BODY

text: Continuous prediction models have historically been less common in the conflict prediction space. However,
label: BODY

text: focus on these models has increased in recent years.
label: BODY

text: The ViEWS research team organized an escalation prediction competition in 2020 and 2021, producing a
label: BODY

text: spate of new research on the topic specifically aimed at solving issues mentioned previously, particularly
label: BODY

text: the ability of models to predict significant changes in conflict.93 While the competition models predicted
label: BODY

text: change in fatalities due to conflict, rather than point estimates of conflict, they are still continuous prediction
label: BODY

text: models. A suite of appropriate metrics were defined for the competition that aim to reward different aspects
label: BODY

text: of a model's performance, and which would be useful for any future research to build on.94
label: BODY

text: 2.3 PERFORMANCE OF CONTINUOUS PREDICTION
label: HH1

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA

text: 95  Iris Malone, 2022.

text: 96  Ibid; Patrick T. Brandt et al., 2022.

label: BODY

text: Burgeoning research but similar issues
label: HH1

text: The research spurred on from the prediction competition has attempted to address many of the problems
label: BODY

text: discussed above. New models that allow for representation of complex conflict dynamics show increased
label: BODY

text: performance in predicting when existing conflict may escalate.95,96 Other models that are built upon dynamic
label: BODY

text: data that captures shifts in conflict risk, such as text data, perform better on predicting the outbreak of
label: BODY

text: conflict in peaceful settings.97 A multitude of other advances and approaches are detailed in the summary
label: BODY

text: paper on the ViEWS competition.98
label: BODY

text: Efficacy of continuous prediction models in predicting conflict
label: HH1

text: Unlike risk prediction models, substantive work has been put into developing metrics for assessing
label: BODY

text: performance of continuous prediction models. The scale of conflict predicted remains too small for likely
label: BODY

text: application in anticipatory action. Performance at the extremes of the distributions should also be tested
label: BODY

text: to see if models are able to predict large-scale escalations in conflict. Most importantly, work on fatality
label: BODY

text: prediction still has no direct linkage to humanitarian impact prediction.
label: BODY
